prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W43A Band 7 (high resolution)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 13CO, 12CO, and 0.9 mm emission toward W43A (high resolution) to yeild the strctures on 0".04-0".4 scales.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The circumstellar envelope and the molecular jet of W43A have velocity widths of 10 km/s and 200 km/s respectively. The spectral resolution of 1 km/s for the envelope lines is enough to resolve the velocity field of the envelope. The minimam observational goal of the proposal is to detect the envelope in 13CO emission. The peak flux density of the 13CO envelope is estimated to be be about 200 mJy, by comparing with the property of another water fountain source IRAS 16342-3814, only from which CO and 13CO J=3->2 emissions are detected (Imai et al. 2012). The estimation is yielded from the CO peak flux density and the size ratio of the jets traced by water maser emission (Imai et al 2002, 2005; Claussen et al. 2009). Even pessimistic case, the envelope will be detected by averaging spectral channels (up to 10 km/s) and combining the dat from two Science Goals. The high velocity jet of W43A will also be detected in brighter CO emission similarly to the 13CO emission (but averaging spectral channels up to 40 km/s).

The circumstellar envelope may be rich in molecular lines, as found towards VY CMa (Kaminski et al. 2013). Wide coverage of spectral windows has benefitial for such rich line detections and data calibration using brighter continuum emission from the target source itself. The spectral resolution is set within the starndard observing mode criteria and still reasolable for reslving the important structures in the source velocity field.

This Science Goal aims to resolve the discrete structure of the W43A bipolar jet, which is found in the periodic and symmetric pattern of the distrinution of water masers. The finest angular resolution (0".04) will resolve this structure. The Goal also aims to resolve the velocity structure of the biconical flow (about 0".02) traced by SiO masers. The velocity centroid map of the 13CO emission can be produved in a relative positional accuracy ammong the velocity channels to be 2 milliarcseconds in the case of S/N ratio to be 10. The largest angular scale (0".4) correspons to the size of the individual lobes of the bipolar jet and that of the inner envelope traced by OH maser emission (Imai et al. 2002).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W43A Band 6 (high resolution)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 12CO, C18O, and 1.3 mm emission toward W43A (high resolution) to yeild the strctures on 0".04-0".5 scales.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The justification is simular to that described in the Science Goal for Band-7 higher resolution mapping. The Band-6 observation in this Science Goal aims to detect the jet and the high density part of the circumstellar envelope of W43A. In the lower-energy molecular transition lines. Different from the Band-7 observations, the Band-6 molecular lines will be significantly contaminated by backgound/foreground emission along the Galactic plane. Therefore, a high dynamic range on the image over 100 is crucial. This will be yielded by combination of the data from the two Band-6 Science Goals.
The justification is similar to that described in the Science Goal for Band-7 high resolution mapping.

This Science Goal aims to resolve the finest structures in the jet and the circumstellar envelope of W43A. Although this Band-6 Science Goal will yield the angular resolution similar to the Band-7 Science Goal, this will find out in detail the angular structures of both the emissions from the background/foreground gas clumps (with a size of 100 AU) and W43A. The emission maps will be also used for extract the background/foreground contributions in the Band-7 data. The intrinsic emission from W43A may be distinguished by finding the region with high CO(J=3->2)/CO(J=2->1) intensity ratio as an indicator of high density region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W43A Band 7 (moderate resolution)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 13CO, 12CO, and 0.9 mm emission toward W43A (moderate resolution) to yeild the strctures on 0".4-7" scales.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The justification is simular to that described in the Science Goal for Band-7 higher resolution mapping. The data of this Science Goal will be used for detecting the intrinsic emission from the W43A envelope and jet together with the high resolution data. In addition, because Galactic background/foreground emission should be filtered out, high dynamic range image is necessary to detect the extended component. The specified sensitivity is necessary to detect possible clumpy structures of the background/foreground whose scale is comparable the sizes of the jets and the envelope.
The justification is similar to that described in the Science Goal for Band-7 high resolution mapping.

This Science Goal aims to recover the whole structure of the jet and the envelope of W43A. The angular resolution corresponds to the largetst scale recovered by the Science Goal for higher angular resolution mapping. The largest angular scale in this Science Goal is a few times larger than the possible largest extents of the jet and envelope whose intrinsic emission is distinguishable from the backgound/foreground emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W43A Band 6 (moderae resolution)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 12CO, C18O, and 1.3 mm emission toward W43A (moderate resolution) to yeild the strctures on 0".5-0".7 scales.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The justification is simular to that described in the Science Goal for Band-6 and 7 mapping in higher angular resolution.
The justification is similar to that described in the Science Goals for Band-6 and 7 high resolution mapping.

The justification is similar to that for the Science Goal of the Band-7 observation in moderate angular resolution. This Science Goal aims to determine the total mass and the mass-loss rates of of the jet and the envelope of W43A.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: "water fountain" sources exhibit collimated, fast bipolar jets from AGB/post-AGB stars traced by water masers. Here we propose imaging of molecular lines including shock traces and continuum emission toward the archetypical water fountain W43A. VLBI observations of H2O, SiO, and OH masers in W43A in milliarcsecond resolution have found bow-shock and point-symmetric clumpy structures in the jet, biconical fast flow in the vicinity of the star, and a spherically and slowly expansion of the circumstellar envelope, respectively. Together with these components, the decadal evolution of the H2O maser distribution and the bipolar morphology of the mid-infrared emission suggest that W43A has just entered the water fountain stage. Before the records of the jet and envelope evolution are lost by the photoionization by the central stellar object to form a planetary nebula, we wish to reveal the whole kinematic and physical structure of W43A in order to unvail the central stellar system. W43A is the most promising source for exploring the central system, i.e., a rotating torus or a binary system in the vicinity (~20 AU) of the central system through sub-mm SiO maser emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00071.S, 'First CO mapping of the "water fountain" sources' (P.I. H. Suzrez) 2011.0.00492.S, 'Evolution of jets and envelopes of "water fountain" sources revealed by continuum emission imaging' (P.I. H. Imai) 2012.1.00264.S, 'First imaging of CO and 1-mm continuum emission towards "water fountain" sources' (P.I. H. Imai) 2013.1.00123.S, 'The collimated jet and the central system of the water fountain source W43A' (P.I. H.Imai)
